description.plain:
With more than 300 million copies of her albums sold, Madonna is the most successful female artist of all time.

Her career as a singer, songwriter, producer and entertainer has spanned almost 40 years, with the release of 13 studio albums, making her impact on pop culture undeniable, inspiring almost every big female act to come up after her.

An activist for LGBT and women’s rights through almost all of her career, she has brought up several controversial topics to the pop music scene such as abortion, sexual freedom, female empowerment and the search for fame.

songs.embed_content: Read “Like a Prayer” by Madonna on Genius

description.plain:
Madonna recorded “Like a Prayer” for her 1989 studio album of the same name. Sire Records released it as the lead single from the album on March 3, 1989.

Written and produced by Madonna and Patrick Leonard, “Like a Prayer” signaled a more artistic and personal approach to songwriting from Madonna, who felt she needed to cater more to her adult audience. The video for the song was quite controversial, primarily for its portrayal of Madonna kissing a black saint and other supposedly sacrilegious religious imagery.

description.plain:
This song, originally written for Michael Jackson about the mythical island of San Pedro, was re-worked by Madonna into her first of many Latin-inspired hits.

The track reflects the multicultural mix of New York that Madonna experienced when she was starting out. She told SongTalk:

When I lived in New York for so many years I was constantly listening to salsa and merengue. I mean, that stuff was constantly blaring out of everybody’s radio on the street."

songs.full_title: Vogue by Madonna

description.plain:
Madonna’s 1990 smash hit “Vogue” was inspired by the dance of the same name and helped make the Queen of Pop a gay icon. Voguing was popular in New York’s underground gay club scene, but Madonna brought it mainstream. Dancers would use hand gestures and make poses emulating their favorite Hollywood stars and cover models.

In late 1989, Madonna was looking to add a b-side to her Like A Prayer single “Keep It Together.” She teamed up with producer Shep Pettibone—who had remixed a number of her songs previously—but they only had a $5,000 budget. Pettibone recalled making the song in an interview with Billboard:

She had the choruses together, and the verses together…That’s how she writes. She’s fast. It’s just like, give her an idea or a direction to go.

Madonna told Rolling Stone in 2009:

I wrote it when I was making Dick Tracy. After we shot the movie, [then-boyfriend] Warren Beatty asked me if I could write a song that would fit my character’s point of view, that she could have conjured up. She was obsessed with speakeasies and movie stars and things like that. The idea for the lyrics came through that request.

In 1990, Pettibone told EW:

We were just after a fun club record. But when the record company bigwigs heard it, they said, ‘This is a No. 1 smash record. Let’s not put it on a B-side and lose it.‘"

When “Vogue” was released, it hit #1 in 30 different countries which made it Madonna’s biggest song ever at the time. It was the best-selling​ single of 1990—having sold over two million copies in the US alone.

songs.embed_content: Read “Material Girl” by Madonna on Genius

description.plain: “Material Girl” is the second single from Like a Virgin. The single was a global sensation, peaking at number-two on the Billboard Hot 100 and reaching the top-five in Australia, Belgium, Canada, Ireland, Japan and United Kingdom. The music video is based off of Marilyn Monroe’s performance of the song “Diamonds Are a Girl’s Best Friend” from the film Gentlemen Prefer Blondes. The single is one of Madonna’s most memorable singles, and is often credited as the start of an “icon”.

songs.embed_content: Read “Bitch I'm Madonna” by Madonna on Genius

description.plain:
“Bitch, I’m Madonna” is the third single off of Madonna’s 13th studio album Rebel Heart.

The title has a fun play at Madonna’s iconic status with a party, club tone beat, co-produced by Diplo. The song also features mogul female rapper, Nicki Minaj. The line “Bitch, I’m Madonna” originally appeared in Kool A.D.’s 2013 single “Eroika.”

songs.full_title: Dark Ballet by Madonna
songs.embed_content: Read “Dark Ballet” by Madonna on Genius

description.plain:
“Dark Ballet” is the second track on Madonna’s fourteenth album, Madame X. The song begins as a piano ballad with Joan of Arc-inspired lyrics before morphing into a monologue told from the point of view of the Maid of Orléans, set to a stomping electronic arrangement of Tchaikovsky’s “Dance of the Reed-Flutes” (from his 1892 ballet, The Nutcracker).

The song was premiered a year earlier under the name “Beautiful Game” when it was excerpted in a medley  performed at the Met Gala on May 8, 2018.

songs.full_title: Papa Don't Preach by Madonna
songs.embed_content: Read “Papa Don't Preach” by Madonna on Genius

description.plain:
Madonna’s controversial hit, hated by feminists and loved by pro-lifers, was inspired by gossiping teenagers overheard by songwriter Brian Elliot. Depending on how one views this song, it could be said to tell a story of a girl passing from the control of her father to the control of her boyfriend, her pregnancy having curtailed her life chances.

More recently, feminists have argued that a strong woman should be the person she wants to be. This may involve having a baby, whatever the circumstances, motherhood being a source of power that should be celebrated.  Therefore the girl in this song is asserting herself, rejecting her father’s control of her, choosing the boy she wants despite her father’s disapproval and deciding her own future.

Listeners can decide their own interpretation.

songs.full_title: Hung Up by Madonna
songs.embed_content: Read “Hung Up” by Madonna on Genius

description.plain:
“Hung Up” is arguably one of Madonna’s most successful and favorable dance tracks in her illustrious career.

Musically the song is synchronized with a sample from ABBA’s “Gimme! Gimme! Gimme! (A Man After Midnight)”. The background element of a ticking clock suggests the fear of wasting time, while the lyrics are written as a traditional dance number about a strong, independent woman who has relationship troubles.

Madonna received permission from both Björn Ulvaeus and Benny Andersson after sending them a heartfelt letter requesting to use their song as a sample. Ulvaeus explained to The Telegraph that it was the first single that he and former band member Benny Andersson gave permission to sample since they gave the nod to Fugees for their song, “Rumble in the Jungle” five years earlier.

We said we would have to listen to it first but after half a minute I knew it was brilliant. That is one of the few we have allowed. […] I think [“Hung Up”] shows that ABBA is part of the DNA set up of Pop.

The world’s thought similarly to Ulvaeus, and “Hung Up” eventually peaked atop the charts of 41 countries (a world record). It was Madonna’s 36th top 10 single on the Billboard Hot 100, tying her with Elvis Presley as the artist with most top ten hits.

Music Video

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EDwb9jOVRtU

songs.embed_content: Read “4 Minutes” by Madonna on Genius

description.plain:
“4 Minutes” is a pop, urban, hip hop song by  Madonna from her eleventh studio album Hard Candy, featuring Justin Timberlake and Timbaland. According to Madonna, the song is about saving the environment and having a good time while we are doing it.

She said about the song:

I don’t think it’s important to take it too literally. I think the song, more than anything, is about having a sense of urgency; about how we are you know, living on borrowed time essentially and people are becoming much more aware of the environment and how we’re destroying the planet. We can’t just keep distracting ourselves we do have to educate ourselves and wake up and do something about it. You know at the same time we don’t want to be boring and serious and not have fun so it’s kind of like well if we’re going to save the planet can we have a good time while we are doing it?

I think the song, more than anything, is about having a sense of urgency; about how we are you know, living on borrowed time essentially and people are becoming much more aware of the environment and how we’re destroying the planet. We can’t just keep distracting ourselves we do have to educate ourselves and wake up and do something about it. You know at the same time we don’t want to be boring and serious and not have fun so it’s kind of like well if we’re going to save the planet can we have a good time while we are doing it?

songs.embed_content: Read “I Don't Give A” by Madonna on Genius

description.plain:
“I Don’t Give A” is a song recorded by American singer-songwriter Madonna for her twelfth studio album MDNA (2012). The song features rap vocals by Trinidadian recording artist Nicki Minaj. It was written and produced by Madonna and Martin Solveig, with additional songwriting by Minaj and Julien Jabre. “I Don’t Give A” is a pop song, with electronic and hip hop syncopated beats.

Lyrically, the song is about a day in Madonna’s life with some portions of it directed at her ex-husband, film director Guy Ritchie, when she sings about a failed marriage. The song received generally favorable reviews from music critics who praised Minaj’s appearance and its personal lyrics. Following the release of MDNA, the song peaked at number 117 in the Gaon Chart of South Korea. Madonna performed the song on The MDNA Tour as the closing track of the show’s first segment.

songs.full_title: Express Yourself by Madonna
songs.embed_content: Read “Express Yourself” by Madonna on Genius

description.plain:
“Express Yourself” was the second single released from Madonna’s Like a Prayer. The anthemic ode to female empowerment was originally a sonic homage to the ‘70s funk-soul of Sly & The Family Stone and The Staples Singers. For radio (and dance clubs) the song was completely overhauled into an electronic-pop banger via a now-legendary Shep Pettibone remix. (It’s this version that was immortalized on the 1990 greatest hits package The Immaculate Collection).

Abetted by a gorgeously elaborate music video directed by David Fincher, “Express Yourself” became a world-wide hit (it reached #2 on the Billboard Hot 100, #5 on the UK singles chart, and #1 on the Billboard Dance chart) and a staple in Madonna’s live sets.

description.plain: Madonna is joined by Brazilian singer Anitta in her version of “Faz Gostoso” from Portuguese singer Blaya—originally released in 2018 as a single. Before getting its own version from the queen of pop herself, the song was already a huge hit in Portugal, where Madonna has been living since 2017.

description.plain:
“Give Me All Your Luvin'” is the first single off Madonna’s 12th studio album, “MDNA”.

The song features Nicki Minaj, M.I.A., and was produced by French DJ, Martin Solvieg.

Madonna performed the song for the first time during the 2012 Super Bowl halftime show.

songs.full_title: Veni Vidi Vici by Madonna (Ft. Nas)
songs.embed_content: Read “Veni Vidi Vici” by Madonna on Genius

description.plain: Madonna teams up with rap legend, Nas to make a new track reminiscing about the past. This is actually the third song in less than a year Nas has made with a pop artist – the other two were with JLo and Mariah Carey. The track sees Madonna incorporating iconic song titles of hers in chronological order of her career throughout her two verses. While incorporating the song titles, she raps about the journey she’s gone through throughout her career to where she is now, with Nas doing the same on his verse.
